edu.jsu.mcis

Class ArgsParser

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.jsu.mcis.ArgsParser

  • public class ArgsParser
extends java.lang.Object

    This program allows the user to add arguments and enter data values into them from the command line. this is an example of how to use this class in the example the string array args would be replaced with the comandline arguments taken form the user

    private ArgsParser ap = new ArgsParser();
    String[] args = new String[] {"7","--digits","10"};
    ap.addProgram("VolumeCalculator","Calculate the volume of a box");
    ap.addPositionalArgument("length","the length of the box",Argument.Type.STRING);
    ap.addNamedArgument("digits","prints help message",Argument.Type.INTEGER,"4","d");
    ap.parseValues(args);

    after the block of code excutes the value stored in the argument length would be "7" and the value of digits would be 10. to obtain the values from this class use the getValue function like so

    ap.getValue("length")

    this would return a 7 if using the above example the user can alos get the data type of any given argumnet by using getArgumentType for length it would return string use like so

    ap.getArgumentType("length")

        public void addNamedArgument(java.lang.String name,
                             java.lang.String description,
                             Argument.Type t,
                             java.lang.String defaultvalue,
                             java.lang.String Shorthand)
        This method adds a named argument to the program.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of the argument.
        description - The description of the argument.
        t - The data type of the argument(String, Integer, Double, Boolean).
        defaultvalue - The default value of the argument.
        Shorthand - The one letter short name of the argument.
        Throws:
        InvalidNameException
